keyTakeAways: A man named Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old pensioner and amateur poet, was sentenced to 21 years in prison for shooting Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
The attack occurred during a public visit to Handlova, about 180km (112 miles) from Bratislava, when Cintula mistakenly believed Fico was a supporter.
Cintula fired five shots at close range, seriously injuring Fico in the abdomen, with his condition described as life-threatening.
The court found Cintula guilty of terrorism, not just attacking a public official, emphasizing the targeted nature of the attack on the prime minister.
Cintula claimed he only wanted to injure Fico to stop policies he believed were harming Slovakia, indicating political motivation.
Fico has accused the opposition of fueling hatred, though he is known for controversial and divisive rhetoric.
The court rejected Cintula's lawyer’s attempt to downgrade the charge to attacking a public official, affirming the severity of the act as terrorism.
Cintula’s legal team plans to appeal the verdict, suggesting ongoing legal and political debate over the case.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In May 2024, Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old pensioner and amateur poet, shot Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico during a public visit to Handlova, about 180km from Bratislava. The attack occurred when Cintula believed Fico was a supporter, and he fired five shots at close range, seriously injuring Fico in the abdomen. Cintula claimed he only wanted to injure Fico to oppose policies he viewed as damaging to Slovakia. Despite his claim of not targeting vital organs, the court found him guilty of terrorism, rejecting his defense to charge as an attack on a public official. Judge Igor Kralik emphasized that the attack was specifically directed at the prime minister, not a random citizen. The case has sparked debate over political extremism and the role of rhetoric in inciting violence, with Fico himself blaming the opposition for fostering hatred, though he is known for controversial statements.
title: Slovak PM Fico's attacker sentenced to 21 years in prison
